paper_abstract: A family of permutations F of [n] = {1, 2,..., n} is (epsilon, k)-min-wise independent if for every nonempty subset X of at most k elements of [n], and for any x epsilon X, the probability that in a random element pi of F, pi(x) is the minimum element of pi(X), deviates from 1/vertical bar X vertical bar by at most epsilon/vertical bar X vertical bar. This notion can be defined for the uniform case, when the elements of F are picked according to a uniform distribution, or for the more general, biased case, in which the elements of F are chosen according to a given distribution D. It is known that this notion is a useful tool for indexing replicated documents on the web. We show that even in the more general, biased case, for all admissible k and epsilon and all large n, the size of F must satisfy |F| >= Omega (k/epsilon(2)log(1/epsilon) log n), as well as |F| >= Omega (k(2)/epsilon log(1/epsilon) log n). This improves the best known previous estimates even for the uniform case.(C) 2007 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.
